title: Rock Cycle and Earth Materials

vocab.kid_friendly_definition: The process that changes one type of rock into another type over long periods of time.
Rock that forms when melted rock (magma or lava) cools and hardens.
Rock formed from layers of sediment that get pressed together over time.
Rock that forms when existing rock is changed by heat and pressure.
The movement of weathered rock and soil from one place to another.
The breaking down of rocks into smaller pieces.
A natural solid material found in rocks.
Small pieces of rock, sand, or dirt.
Melted rock that comes out of a volcano.

teachingNotes: Use rock samples if available. Create models showing the rock cycle. Discuss how rocks change very slowly over millions of years.

sample.question: What type of rock forms when lava cools and hardens?

truefalse.question: All rocks on Earth stay the same type forever.
Sedimentary rocks form from layers of sediment.
Igneous rocks form from melted rock that cooled.
Weathering and erosion can change rocks over time.
Metamorphic rocks form without heat or pressure.
The rock cycle can take millions of years.
All rocks began as sedimentary rocks.

shortanswer.question: Explain how the rock cycle shows that Earth is always changing.
expectedAny: processes like melting, pressure, and erosion

shortanswer.question: Describe two ways an igneous rock could become sedimentary.
expectedAny: weather to sediment then press into layers
erode, deposit, then compact and cement

shortanswer.question: How does heat and pressure change rock into metamorphic rock?
Give an example of each rock type.
What role does water play in the rock cycle?
Why do we say the rock cycle has no beginning or end?
expectedAny: rocks can change from any type to another over time
rocks are recycled again and again

shortanswer.question: How might a volcano affect the rock cycle?
expectedAny: ash and lava create new rocks
